TextEquiv.Unicode: Species 13. (Fig. a, Mus. Saul; Fig. b and c, Mus. Cuming.)

CASSIS TENUIS. Cass. testâ ovato-oblongâ, cylindraceâ, Cyprœœformi, tenuiculâ, spirâ brevissimâ, anfractibus lœvibus, transversim regulariter sulcatis, sulcis binis, interstitiis longitudinaliter obtusè liratis, tuberculorum seriebus quatuor armatis; columellâ vix concavâ, su‐ pernè: et infernè rugatâ, labro externa peculiariter reﬂexo, fortiter dentato-lirato, liris binis; aperturâ elongatâ, extremitatibus ambabus canaliculatis; pur- pureo-fuscâ, livido-cœruleo nebulatâ, sulcis lirisque dor- salibus cœruleo-albidis, columellâ purpureo-nigrâ, rugis albis, labro columellari basin versus rufo vividè tinctâ, areâ pone labrum externum purpureo-nigro conspicuè maculatâ.

THE THIN CASSIS. Shell ovately-oblong, cylindrical, Cowry-shaped, rather thin, spire very short, whorls smooth, transversely regularly grooved, grooves two and two, interstices longitudinally obtusely ridged, armed with four rows of tubercles; columella slightly concave, wrinkled above and below, outer lip pecu‐ liarly reﬂected, strongly dentately ridged, ridges in pairs, aperture elongated, both extremities channelled; purple-brown, clouded with livid blue, dorsal grooves and ridges white, columella stained towards the base with bright red, area behind the outer lip conspi‐ cuously blotched with purple-black.
Hab. Gallapagos Islands (in sandy mud at the depth of six fathoms); Cuming.

M. Deshayes in his notice of this species likens it to the C. testiculus; the accompanying ﬁgure of a mature specimen shows, however, that it is much more nearly allied to the C. rufa. In its most advanced stage of growth the shell is comparatively thin, the lip being curled back without any great deposit of enamel; the general form is more
cylindrically oblong than that of C. rufa, and the aperture- is wider. The colour and marking are extremely pretty.

The C. tenuis, of which a very small but accurate ﬁgure was published by Mr. Wood in his supplement to the ‘Index Testaceologicus,’ has been very generally mistaken by English collectors for Lamarck’s C. pennata, which is merely the young of C. rufa.

CASSIS COARCTATA. Cass, testâ cylindraceo-ovatâ, cras- siusculâ, spirâ brevi, anfractibus evaricosis, transversim tenuissimè striatis, costis nodulosis cingulatis, quarum quatuor cœteris majoribus; columellâ breviplicatâ et obliquè subtiliter rugatâ, labro intus dentato-lirato, supernè coarctato, non reﬂexo, aperturâ elongatâ, an- gustâ; cinereo-albidâ, purpureo-fusco tinctâ, nodulis nonnullis albicantibus, columellâ labrogue rufescentibus.

THE CONTRACTED HELMET. Shell cylindrically ovate, rather thick, spire short, whorls destitute of varices, transversely very ﬁnely striated, encircled by nodulous ribs, four of which are larger than the rest; columella shortly plicated, and obliquely ﬁnely wrinkled, lip dentately ridged within, contracted at the upper part, not reﬂected, aperture elongated and narrow; ash- white, stained with purple-brown, some of the nodules whitish, lip and columella reddish.
Hab. Gallapagos Islands, Paciﬁc Ocean (in crevices of rocks); Cuming.

The contraction of the outer lip, which is always con‐ stant, is a singular feature in this species. For the mag‐ niﬁcent specimen here represented, which is of unusually large size, I am indebted to the choice collection of Miss Saul.
GRAY, Wood Index Test. Supp. pl. 4. f. 5. Cyprœacassis coarctata, Stutchbury.
GRAY, Wood Index Test. Supp. pl. 4. f. 4. Cassis Massenœ, Kiener.
